title: So Inspiring! Pranjal Patil, First Visually Impaired IAS Officer, Takes Charge
text:
With passion and determination, anything is possible! Recently, Pranjal Patil became India's first visually impaired woman IAS officer, who took charge as sub-collector of Kerala’s Thiruvananthapuram district. Here’s her story...

Meet Pranjal Patil, the country’s new hero!

Pranjal, the country’s newfound hero, hails from Ulhas Nagar in Maharashtra. She lost her vision at the age of six due to direct exposure to sunlight, but her spirit was undefeated. The relentless young woman studied in Kamala Mehta Dadar School for the blind, and during those years, underwent several operations to reattach her retinas, all of which were unfortunately unsuccessful.

Explaining her journey to a leading daily, Pranjal said: “I had high-powered glasses since I was a child, and then I lost sight in both my eyes in quick succession. Despite that, I was carrying on with my daily activities as usual, and because I was young, it didn’t impact me as such. When the surgeries were done, I did suffer a lot. The pain did not subside until at least a year after the surgery.”

Pranjal’s inspiring journey to becoming an IAS officer

After completing her schooling, followed by a B.A. in Political Science from St. Xavier’s College, Mumbai, Pranjal went on to enroll for a masters in International Relations from Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). Post that, she was admitted into an integrated M.Phil. and Ph.D. programme.

Talking about what motivated her to pursue a career in civil services, Pranjal revealed: “My exposure to the culture of JNU helped build confidence in my mind to work for the right cause. The vibrant environment of the university taught me to form opinions and ask the right questions; this gave me the courage to be a civil service officer. While I had decided to write the UPSC exam when I was doing my graduate degree, I had made up my mind by the time I was in JNU.”

Living the life she imagined

During her time at JNU, Pranjal claims she believed that attending too many coaching classes would have ruined her overall experience, and she would “miss out” on all the fun. She said: “If I were to attend coaching classes, I would miss out on several aspects of my life as a JNU student. I did solve mock papers and attended discussions, though.” Pranjal cracked the exam on her first attempt in 2016, where she was placed 773rd. She went on to securing the 124th place in 2017.

In a country like ours, where often, children are pushed into becoming doctors and engineers--the only socially acceptable jobs that Indian parents can enjoy boasting about--Pranjal’s take is refreshing and relevant. She told a newspaper: “No individual should be pressured into doing something forcibly. Instead of succumbing to competition, one should focus on sharpening their skills and working on their weaknesses. This would, in turn, let a person function to their full potential.”

A solid support system

As Pranjal officially stepped into her role as sub-collector on 14 October 2019, she shared how her parents’ support has played an important role in her success. “My parents have always supported me, despite the tough challenges we’ve had to face. It’s just that with effort, we all will get that one big breakthrough that we want. We never felt defeated and we never gave up.”

The 31-year-old will hold the position of Assistant Collector for a year, as part of her training period, whose first leg she completed at Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration, Mussoorie. After her field-training in Kochi, she will head back to Mussoorie next year to wrap up her training, at the end of which she is expected to submit a dissertation.

“I expect a lot of support from the people of Thiruvananthapuram and the staff here to be able to work for the people,” Pranjal said, post signing the Report of Transfer of Charge to take over from Sam Cleetus, the Deputy Collector (Land Acquisition), who had been holding charge of Sub-Collector.

Here’s wishing this go-getter all the best in her future endeavours!
description: Pranjal Patil has become India’s very first visually impaired IAS Officer, who took charge as sub-collector of Kerala’s Thiruvananthapuram district. Here’s her inspiring story.
